content: I love this photo. The little guy on the other side of Berlusconi is Dmitry Medvedev, the Russian premier. Haven't seen anything like that in a long time...

content: quote: Originally posted by mcgreer: I love this photo. The little guy on the other side of Berlusconi is Dmitry Medvedev, the Russian premier. Haven't seen anything like that in a long time... It's time for another episode of Who That Guy Look Like? To the left of the President, former Washington governor, current commerace secretary, Gary Locke. The real Locke On the Presidents left is none other than college hoops guy, Dick Vitale! The real Vitale Is it just me or does Medvedev look like a used car salesman... And on the right is basketball great "Sir' Charles Barkley! the real Chucky B

content: Put 'em all in jeans and a t-shirt, and they're just another dude slogging through life...

title: A New Era in US/Russian Relations?

content: I believe Obama & Medvedev can ultimately find common ground! They have a few things in common; both are fairly young (not stuck in CW mentality) & both trained as lawyers! quote: Signs of a thaw in U.S.-Russian relations solidified on April 1 after U.S. President Barack Obama and his Russian counterpart Dmitry Medvedev held their first face-to-face meeting, on the sidelines of the G20 summit in London. (....) "Everything does not depend exclusively on Obama and Medvedev. Much depends on the respective elites in the two countries," says Yevgeny Volk, head of the Moscow branch of the conservative Heritage Foundation think-tank. "It must be said that Russia has a significant amount of distrust for America. And the United States, for its part, also has a basis for not completely trusting Russia." That mistrust is still evident in the way the two sides view the war between Russia and neighboring Georgia in August 2008. The two presidents conceded in their statement that Moscow and Washington continue to disagree about the "causes and sequence of the military actions" in the five-day war. When Russian troops invaded Georgia after Tbilisi tried to recapture the pro-Moscow breakaway region of South Ossetia by force in August, it marked a post-Cold War nadir in Washington's relations with Moscow. The United States has forged close ties with Tbilisi and had been a strong advocate of Georgia joining NATO. Moscow, which sees the South Caucasus as its sphere of influence, has staunchly opposed this. A senior U.S. administration official said that in their meeting, Obama and Medvedev "had real disagreements about Georgia." The official said that Obama made it clear to the Russian leader that Moscow's desire for a "sphere of influence" in the former Soviet Union was "an idea whose time is long past." The two presidents also acknowledged that there were lingering differences over Washington's plans to build elements of a missile defense system in Central Europe. But they held out the possibility of future cooperation on the issue. Obama has shown less enthusiasm for the missile-defense proposal than his predecessor George W. Bush and has indicated to Medvedev that Washington would consider scrapping the idea if Moscow assisted in curbing Tehran's nuclear ambitions. Since coming to office in January, the Obama administration has stressed its desire to "press the reset button" with Russia and improve relations, which have steadily deteriorated in recent years. The Kremlin has made clear it expects Washington to initiate the effort by offering concessions. White House press secretary Robert Gibbs says, however, that restoring relations will take efforts from both sides. Gibbs told reporters this week that "nobody believes that change in our relationship means giving everyone all they want... That's certainly not the intention of the president." Volk says that thawing relations between Moscow and Washington will be a "long and difficult" process, especially once it becomes apparent the hard trade-offs that each side will be forced to make in order to improve relations. "If you take any international problem, there is more tension between Russia and the United States than there is common ground," Volk said. +http://www.rferl.org/content/Moscow_Washington_Try_To_Lead_By_Example_On_Arms_Control/1566069.html "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
quote: Signs of a thaw in U.S.-Russian relations solidified on April 1 after U.S. President Barack Obama and his Russian counterpart Dmitry Medvedev held their first face-to-face meeting, on the sidelines of the G20 summit in London. (....) "Everything does not depend exclusively on Obama and Medvedev. Much depends on the respective elites in the two countries," says Yevgeny Volk, head of the Moscow branch of the conservative Heritage Foundation think-tank. "It must be said that Russia has a significant amount of distrust for America. And the United States, for its part, also has a basis for not completely trusting Russia." That mistrust is still evident in the way the two sides view the war between Russia and neighboring Georgia in August 2008. The two presidents conceded in their statement that Moscow and Washington continue to disagree about the "causes and sequence of the military actions" in the five-day war. When Russian troops invaded Georgia after Tbilisi tried to recapture the pro-Moscow breakaway region of South Ossetia by force in August, it marked a post-Cold War nadir in Washington's relations with Moscow. The United States has forged close ties with Tbilisi and had been a strong advocate of Georgia joining NATO. Moscow, which sees the South Caucasus as its sphere of influence, has staunchly opposed this. A senior U.S. administration official said that in their meeting, Obama and Medvedev "had real disagreements about Georgia." The official said that Obama made it clear to the Russian leader that Moscow's desire for a "sphere of influence" in the former Soviet Union was "an idea whose time is long past." The two presidents also acknowledged that there were lingering differences over Washington's plans to build elements of a missile defense system in Central Europe. But they held out the possibility of future cooperation on the issue. Obama has shown less enthusiasm for the missile-defense proposal than his predecessor George W. Bush and has indicated to Medvedev that Washington would consider scrapping the idea if Moscow assisted in curbing Tehran's nuclear ambitions. Since coming to office in January, the Obama administration has stressed its desire to "press the reset button" with Russia and improve relations, which have steadily deteriorated in recent years. The Kremlin has made clear it expects Washington to initiate the effort by offering concessions. White House press secretary Robert Gibbs says, however, that restoring relations will take efforts from both sides. Gibbs told reporters this week that "nobody believes that change in our relationship means giving everyone all they want... That's certainly not the intention of the president." Volk says that thawing relations between Moscow and Washington will be a "long and difficult" process, especially once it becomes apparent the hard trade-offs that each side will be forced to make in order to improve relations. "If you take any international problem, there is more tension between Russia and the United States than there is common ground," Volk said.

content: Russia and the US were allies in WWII and today we are more alike than back then. As neighbors off our coast we need to work hard to get along.
reply: Russia and the US were allies in WWII and today we are more alike than back then. As neighbors off our coast we need to work hard to get along.
